texts.shortText: Uncommonly seen and usually solitary. Fairly easily recognized by the elongate, flexible body that tapers towards anterior end, presence of a sucker at each end of the body, inchworm-like mode of locomotion and particularly by ring of wart-like tubercles on each body segment.
Body length typically about 20 mm, but can be up to 50 mm.

Global: Widespread in Indo-Pacific and recently observed by C.L. Griffiths in Namibia.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Mozambique.

A long-known but only fairly recently formally described species.  Parasitic on a wide range of fish species in both fully marine and estuarine habitats. Infests cultured fish in Australia, the Philippines and Malaysia, causing mortality among infected fish and causing secondary bacterial infections.

In South Africa has been found on a variety of coastal fishes, as well as freely moving around under boulders on rocky shores. Known to be responsible for transmitting hemogragarine and trypanopome blood parasites between various species of coastal fishes in the region.
Feeds on the blood of a variety of fish species, especially klipfishes (family Clinidae).

Leeches are hermaphrodite and although some species brood their young, most lay their eggs in a cocoon. In this species cocoons take about 7 days to hatch at 27 C and only another 9-10 days was required for juveniles to grow into mature adults. Self-fertilization has also been reported in this species.

Very few marine leeches have been reported from South Africa and this is the only common species found free-living in the intertidal zone. It is unlikely to be confused with any other regional leech due to the wart-like tubercles on the body.
